keyTakeAways: The Louvre museum in Paris was the target of a daylight robbery where over €88 million worth of high-value jewellery was stolen.
The stolen items include a diamond and emerald necklace given by Emperor Napoleon to his wife, a tiara worn by Empress Eugenie, and pieces previously owned by Queen Marie-Amelie.
Four masked thieves used a truck with a mechanical lift and a battery-powered disc cutter to breach the museum's security, entering through a glass window in the Galerie d'Apollon.
Thieves threatened guards, evacuated the building, and were seen fleeing on scooters after attempting to set fire to their vehicle, which was stopped by a museum staff member.
A damaged crown belonging to Empress Eugenie was found on the escape route, indicating the thieves fled in haste.
Security flaws were identified, including one in three rooms lacking CCTV and a failure in the broader alarm system, which allowed the intrusion.
French President Emmanuel Macron called the incident an attack on France's cultural heritage.
Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin criticized security protocol failures, stating that the incident has left France with a 'terrible image'.
Authorities believe the thieves are professionals due to the speed and organization of the heist.
Experts warn that the stolen jewellery is likely already broken down into precious metals and gems, smuggled out and sold for a fraction of value.
Public prosecutor Laure Beccuau emphasized that the real loss is to France’s historical heritage, not just the monetary value.
The French government has responded by tightening security measures around all cultural institutions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A daring daylight heist at the Louvre museum in Paris saw four masked thieves steal jewellery valued at €88 million, including items gifted by Napoleon I to his wife and a tiara worn by Empress Eugenie. The thieves used a modified truck and a battery-powered disc cutter to breach the museum within eight minutes of opening, threatening guards and fleeing on scooters. A damaged crown linked to Empress Eugenie was found on their escape route. Security flaws, including missing CCTV in one in three rooms and a non-triggered alarm system, were identified. French leaders, including President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin, condemned the incident as a national attack on cultural heritage. Experts believe the stolen items are likely already broken down into metals and gems and smuggled out of the country, emphasizing the irreversible loss to France’s historical legacy.
